title-group.article-title: Menopause Across Asia: A Comprehensive Meta-analysis of Age and Influencing Factors

article-meta.aff: Department of Medicine, Sarojini Naidu Medical College, Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India
1Department of General Medicine, Noida International Institute of Medical Sciences, Gautam Buddha Nagar, Uttar Pradesh, India
2Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Sarojini Naidu Medical College, Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: The irreversible cessation of menstruation, menopause, is a significant event in a woman’s life. Its timing varies widely across populations and is influenced by genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors. Data from various Asian countries such as India, Pakistan, China, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Thailand was synthesised to examine the average age of menopause and identify regional variations, and explore associated determinants. Systematic review and metaanalysis were conducted following PRISMA guidelines. Datawere gathered from electronic databases including PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, and Google Scholar. The analysis included population based and cohort studies reporting mean age at natural menopause, whereas those focusing on premature ovarian insufficiency or surgical menopause were excluded. Random-effects models were applied for pooled estimates, and subgroup analyses were performed based on socioeconomic status, residence, body mass index, smoking, and education. The results revealed pooled mean age of menopause ranged from 46.36 years in Pakistan to 52.0 years in Indonesia. Urban women experienced later menopause than rural women (49 vs. 46.5 years). Higher BMI, socioeconomic status, parity, and education were associated with delayedmenopause, whereas smoking, alcohol use, stressful and physically demanding workload, and early menarche were linked with earlier onset. These findings highlight that the age at menopause varies significantly.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Menopause signifies the irreversible cessation of menstruation, defined by 12 consecutive months without a menstrual period, marking the end of a woman’s reproductive years. It usually occurs between the ages of 45 and 55, with a global average around 51 years. The biological transition is driven by the decline in ovarian follicular activity, leading to reduced estrogen and progesterone levels.[1] This hormonal shift not only signals the end of fertility but also introduces a range of physiological and psychological changes that can impact overall health and quality of life. Symptoms such as hot flashes, night sweats, mood swings, and vaginal dryness are common, while long-term consequences may include osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease, and metabolic disorders. Given its widespread impact, menopause is a critical marker of aging and reproductive health, warranting focused research and attention.[2]

The age at which menopause occurs is influenced by a combination of genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors. It serves as an important indicator of ovarian reserve and overall reproductive aging. Early menopause, defined as occurring before the age of 40, may be associated with increased risks of cardiovascular diseases, osteoporosis, and mortality, whereas later menopause may heighten the risk of breast and endometrial cancers.[3] Consequently, understanding the determinants of menopausal age is essential for predicting health outcomes and planning interventions to mitigate associated risks. The study of menopausal age is particularly relevant in public health as it provides insights into women’s health trends and facilitates the development of preventive measures and healthcare policies.[4]

Research has shown considerable variability in the age of menopause across different countries and regions, driven by genetic predisposition, dietary habits, socioeconomic conditions, and environmental exposures.[5] For instance, studies in Western countries report higher average menopausal ages compared to many Asian and African nations. Within Asia, the diversity in cultural practices, nutritional patterns, and healthcare accessibility further contributes to this variability. Moreover, urbanization and modernization have led to changes in lifestyle, physical activity levels, and obesity rates, which are also known to influence menopausal timing.[6] Despite the significance of these factors, region-specific data on menopausal age and its determinants remain limited, especially in Asian populations.

Given the rapid socioeconomic and demographic transitions in Asia, it is crucial to examine trends and patterns in menopausal age to address public health challenges effectively. Dietary transitions, increased stress levels, delayed childbearing, and higher rates of obesity and metabolic syndrome have the potential to alter menopausal patterns. Furthermore, differences in rural and urban settings, as well as variations in socioeconomic status, can create disparities in health outcomes related to menopause. These observations emphasize the need for comprehensive studies that assess menopausal age and its associated factors within the Asian context.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: The primary objectives of this meta-analysis are to determine the average age of menopause in selected Asian countries, assess temporal trends and influencing factors, and identify regional variations and associated determinants. By synthesizing data from multiple studies, this research aims to provide robust estimates of menopausal age and explore the heterogeneity observed across populations. The findings will not only improve our understanding of menopause in Asia but also contribute to the development of targeted health strategies that address the specific needs of women across different regions.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This study was a systematic review and meta-analysis conducted in accordance with PRISMA guidelines to evaluate the average age of menopause across selected Asian countries.

sec.title: Protocol and registration
sec.p: This review was not prospectively registered in PROSPERO or any other systematic review registry. The methodology was determined a priori and followed throughout the study.

sec.title: Data sources and search strategy
sec.p: A comprehensive search was conducted from January 1989 to March 2024 across four electronic databases, including PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, and Google Scholar, was performed. Search strings included: (“age of menopause” OR “menopausal age” OR “natural menopause”) AND (“Asia” OR “India” OR “Pakistan” OR “China” OR “Malaysia” OR “Japan” OR “South Korea” OR “Thailand” OR “UAE.” Boolean operators were applied, and searches were limited to title/abstract fields and English language publications. Two independent reviewers screened all titles and abstracts. Full texts were retrieved and reviewed independently. Disagreements were resolved by discussion or consultation with a third reviewer.

list-item.p: Population-based or cohort studies that reported the mean age of menopause
Studies were conducted in the specified countries.
Studies focusing on premature ovarian insufficiency or surgical menopause
Case reports, reviews, animal studies, and nonpeer-reviewed publications.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Meta-analysis was performed to estimate the pooled mean age at natural menopause (ANM) using random-effects models (DerSimonian and Laird method), accounting for between-study heterogeneity. Standard errors and confidence intervals were calculated where missing, using available means, standard deviations, and sample sizes. Study weights were assigned by inverse variance. Heterogeneity was assessed using the I² statistic (I² >75% = substantial). Subgroup analyses were conducted based on socioeconomic status, urban–rural residence, education, body mass index (BMI), and region. Due to missing standard errors, publication bias assessment (e.g., Egger’s test, funnel plot) was not feasible. Meta-regression was considered but not conducted due to insufficient continuous covariate data. Analyses were done using IBM SPSS Statistics v28.1 and Microsoft Excel; forest plots were cross-validated in MetaXL.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Out of 222 references, which were identified from various databases (electronic and others), 56 duplicates were removed. Subsequently, 84 references were excluded after they failed to meet the inclusion criteria. Full texts were reviewed for the remaining 82 articles, and the final synthesis included 34 studies covering populations from China, India, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Iran, and Indonesia. A PRISMA flow diagram illustrating the selection process is presented in Figure 1.

caption.p: Forest plot of mean age at menopause by study

sec.title: Study characteristics
sec.p: The studies included in our meta-analysis reflect a broad geographical distribution across Asia, with China having the greatest number of studies (9 studies, total sample size: 259,570), followed by India (6 studies, total sample size: 4144) and Pakistan (6 studies, total sample size: 3379). Other countries, including Malaysia, South Korea, Japan, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, and Iran, also contributed valuable data, with each contributing one to four studies each. There was a significant diversity in the mean ages at natural menopause, ranging from 44.5 years (Pakistan) to 52.34 years (Malaysia). An overview of studies from each country with their mean age of menopause, along with sample sizes and study characteristics, is summarized in Table 1.

caption.p: Summary of country-wise study on average age of menopause

tr.td: Blue collar workers - 49.0 White collar workers - 49.5

sec.title: Results of individual studies [Table 1]
sec.p: Estimated mean age of menopause varied across different regions. China, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia (based on one study, though conclusions should be made cautiously due to limited data) have consistently reported the occurrence of menopause at higher ages (≥48.25 years). Among them, the highest mean age of menopause was 52.34 years (Alwi et al., 2021)[28] in Malaysia, with Indonesia trailing slightly by 52.0 years.[29]

Menopausal age in China’s nine studies ranged from 47.22 to 51.0 years, with notable subgroup findings, such as occupational differences reported by Wang et al.,[19] and rural–urban differences by An and Li.[22]

Conversely, studies from India, Pakistan, and to some extent Sri Lanka, reported lower menopause ages with mean ages at or below 46.37 years. The earliest average menopausal age was 44.5 years, reported by Adhi et al.[16] in Pakistan. Relatively earlier mean age of menopause was also reported in India, with estimates ranging from 44.92 to 47.9 years, and several studies clustered around 46.2 years. Studies by Dasgupta and Ray[7] observed a significant rural–urban gap, with urban women reaching menopausal age nearly 2 years earlier than their rural counterparts.

These results can be believed to reflect a trend with later menopause being more common in economically developed and urbanized settings, while earlier menopause is more frequently observed in South Asian contexts, particularly among rural or lower-income populations.

sec.title: Statistical synthesis
sec.p: A meta-analysis was carried out to estimate the average menopausal age from 34 studies conducted across 12 different countries, consisting of a total of 1,578,572 women. The mean ANM showed variability ranging from 45.86 years in Pakistan to 51.43 years in Malaysia. While south Asian countries, such as India (46.37 years) and Pakistan (46.36) showed menopause appearing earlier, while Sri Lanka had a relatively higher mean age of 48.25 years aligning more with countries in East and Southeast Asia, such as Indonesia (52.0 years), South Korea (50.01 years), Japan (49.08 years), Thailand (49.56 years), and Malaysia (50.11 years) reporting relatively higher average age of menopause. In most countries, the range of estimates (shown by the 95% confidence intervals) was quite narrow since the studies had large robust sample sizes and their results were fairly consistent. However, there was still a high level of variation between the studies (with I2 values between 95.65% and 99.99%). Suggesting that the differences in menopause age were due to the presence of various other factors such as education, economic status, lifestyle, and demography profession. Thus, suggesting that these variables act as a substantial source of interstudy heterogeneity in average menopausal age estimates.

sec.title: Reporting biases
sec.p: Formal statistical assessments of publication bias, such as Egger’s test, Begg’s test, or funnel plot asymmetry analysis, could not be performed due to the unavailability of standard errors and confidence intervals in a majority of the included studies. These missing parameters limited the ability to generate a reliable funnel plot or perform regression-based methods to detect small-study effects. Although some smaller studies (e.g., Adhi et al.,[16] Prasad et al.,[11] Dasgupta et al.[7]) reported relatively lower mean ages at menopause, it is not possible to determine whether this reflects true population-level variation, selective reporting, or a small-study effect. Therefore, the presence or absence of publication bias cannot be confirmed or excluded in this meta-analysis. Further studies reporting complete statistical parameters – including standard errors, confidence intervals, and raw data – would allow more robust assessments of potential reporting biases.

The Newcastle–Ottawa Scale (NOS) was used to assess the risk of bias across 34 observational studies included in this review [Table 2]. The NOS evaluates studies based on three domains: Selection (up to 4 points), comparability (up to 2 points), and outcome (up to 3 points), with a total possible score of 9. Based on total scores, studies were classified as low risk of bias (7–9 points), moderate risk (4–6 points), or high risk (<4 points). In this analysis, 13 studies (38%) were rated as low risk, 18 studies (53%) as moderate risk, and 3 studies (9%) as high risk. The low-risk studies were generally larger, better reported, and more consistent in their methodology, particularly those from China, Korea, and large multicenter cohorts. High-risk studies were typically smaller, older, and lacked detail on selection or outcome assessment.

caption.p: Newcastle–Ottawa Scale Assessment with risk levels

sec.title: Certainty of evidence
sec.p: Using a GRADE-style interpretation, the certainty of evidence is moderate to high for associations involving education, socioeconomic status, BMI, and urban residence. These findings are supported by multiple studies with large sample sizes and internal consistency – particularly in China, Korea, and Malaysia. In contrast, the evidence for alcohol use, smoking, and age at menarche is lower in certainty, due to variability in measurement, fewer contributing studies, and smaller sample sizes. While biologically plausible, these associations would benefit from more direct, consistently measured data in future studies. Findings have been summarized in Table 3.

caption.p: GRADE evidence table: Age at natural menopause

sec.p: High heterogeneity (I²) was observed across countries. For instance, China (99.99%), India (98.44%), Pakistan (99.89%), and Malaysia (99.79%) demonstrated substantial between-study variability. Moderate-to-high heterogeneity was also seen in South Korea (95.65%), Sri Lanka (97.77%), and Thailand (98.95%).

sec.title: Subgroup analysis of factors influencing age at natural menopause
sec.p: A subgroup analysis was also conducted to study the presence of heterogeneity in ANM across different countries. The results highlighted that the variation of ANM across different Asian countries was influenced by several demographic, lifestyle, and socioeconomic factors [Table 4].

Several studies suggest that women with higher education tend to experience menopause later, potentially due to indirect benefits such as improved nutrition, healthcare access, and reproductive planning. In particular, studies from China,[19] India,[1017] Malaysia,[26] and Korea[32] observed this trend. However, these findings were often specific to certain subpopulations (e.g., rural or low-income groups) and should not be generalized to the entire population, especially in highly diverse countries like India.

Similarly, lower socioeconomic status was associated with earlier menopause in some studies conducted in India,[101112] Pakistan,[18] and China.[19] These associations may reflect limited access to health services and nutritional resources, but again, they are context-dependent and vary across geographic and demographic lines.

BMI and nutritional status served as important biological predictors. Six studies from China,[253233] India,[1217] and Korea[3132] reported that higher BMI was associated with females experiencing menopause at later stages of life. Meanwhile, two studies from India[11] and Sri Lanka[17] highlighted that poor nutritional status contributed to earlier menopause.

Lifestyle habits clearly affected the age of menopause clearly. Smoking, in particular, was consistently linked with earlier menopause, as concluded in four studies from China,[1925] South Korea,[32] and Sri Lanka.[17] Similarly, alcohol consumption was associated with earlier onset of menopause in studies from India[12] and South Korea.[33] These findings strengthen the idea that exposure to toxins accelerates reproductive aging.

Parity also influenced menopausal timing in the studied females. Two studies from India[10] and China[19] reported that women with higher parity experienced later menopause, possibly due to reduced cumulative ovulation or hormonal protection during pregnancy.

Urban versus rural residence demonstrated variable trends. While two studies from China[22] and Pakistan[18] reported that urban women experienced later menopause, one study from India[7] displayed the opposite trend. These inconsistent conclusions suggest that urbanization effects may differ by region, reflecting varying degrees of environmental exposure, stress, and health service utilization.

Occupational status had a meaningful contribution to the analysis, with evidence from China[20] and India[8] indicating that women in manual or lower-skilled jobs experienced earlier menopause. This may reflect chronic physical strain or limited workplace support.

Finally, menopausal age was also influenced by the age at which menarche emerged. Two studies, one from Indonesia[29] and one from Korea,[32] showed that earlier menarche (especially ≤11 years) was associated with increased risk of premature or earlier menopause, highlighting a compressed reproductive window.
Findings of subgroup analysis are summarized in Table 5.

caption.p: Subgroup analysis of factors influencing age at natural menopause

fn.p: ANM: Age at natural menopause, BMI: Body mass index.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The meta-analysis revealed that when compared to Western countries, ANM in Asia is comparatively lower. Researchers in the US, UK, and Eastern Europe have reported an average ANM of about 50–52 years as compared to the present analysis found in our pooled estimates, ranging from 45.86 to 51.43 years in Asian populations. These regional variations are ascribed to an amalgamation of socioeconomic status, lifestyle factors, genetic predisposition, and healthcare access playing a role in menopause timing.

A study on a multi-ethnic US cohort reported an average ANM of 51.4 years.[41] In that study, menopause appeared later in females with higher education, BMI, and use of oral contraceptive, whereas smoking and lower socioeconomic status were associated with earlier menopause. Ethnic variations pointed toward genetic and lifestyle factors influencing the menopause timing. Our findings are consistent with these results, particularly the associations involving education, BMI, and smoking. However, the average age of ANM in Asia (pooled range: 45.86–51.43 years) was lower than that in the US, possibly due to better health care, nutrition, and lifestyle differences. Earlier ANM in low-resource settings may prompt the need for earlier screening for osteoporosis and cardiovascular risk.

Similar results were shown in Central and Eastern Europe (Russia, Czech Republic, and Poland)[42] who have reported a median ANM of 50–52 years, with factors such as education, vitamin supplement use, and oral contraceptive use leading to delayed menopause, while smoking, and alcohol abstinence causing menopause to be experienced earlier. While some studies from India and China suggest that women engaged in intense physical labor tend to experience earlier menopause – possibly due to chronic physiological stress – others have reported an association between low physical activity and earlier menopause, likely reflecting poor overall health or sedentary lifestyles. These seemingly opposing findings highlight the need for more nuanced investigation into the type and context of physical activity. Our analysis further showed that within Asia, ANM varies considerably across countries. Later menopause was more common in China, Korea, and Malaysia – possibly due to better nutrition, higher education, and greater access to reproductive healthcare. In contrast, India, Pakistan, and several other South Asian countries showed earlier menopause, which may be linked to socioeconomic disadvantages, undernutrition, smoking, and limited access to health care. It is important to note, however, that these associations were observed in specific subpopulations and do not apply uniformly across the Indian population, given its substantial regional, nutritional, and educational diversity. Substantial heterogeneity was observed (I² >95%), likely due to differences in population characteristics, socioeconomic profiles, and study methodologies. Due to incomplete covariate reporting, meta-regression was not feasible. Subgroup analyses were used to explore heterogeneity.

sec.title: Limitations of the evidence included in the review
sec.p: Despite the large sample size and broad geographic representation and presence of a comprehensive scope of this review, several limitations should be recognized. Many used studies relied on self-reporting methods for estimating menopausal age, leading to the introduction of recall bias. Menopausal age may be culturally sensitive, and self-reporting may involve social desirability bias. Confounding factors such as diet, parity, hormonal contraceptive use, and chronic illness were inconsistently reported or controlled across studies, limiting the accuracy and comparability of ANM estimates. The number of studies per country is also not equal, with the maximum number of studies from China contributing the largest sample size, while countries like Iran and Indonesia contributed with just a single study each. This imbalance restricts the generalizability of findings to underrepresented regions and should be interpreted with caution.

The heterogeneity was also included in the analysis because of varying methodologies, sample sizes, and study designs (cross-sectional vs. longitudinal) used during the process. While subgroup and sensitivity analyses were conducted, unexplained variability still remains, suggesting that additional factors influencing menopause timing may not have been fully captured. Finally, the possibility of publication bias cannot be excluded, as studies with insignificant findings may be underreported in the literature.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: The findings of this meta-analysis reflected a considerable variation in the ANM across Asian countries, shown to be having lower average ANM compared to Western populations. Later menopause was more commonly observed in countries with relatively better socioeconomic indicators, such as China and Malaysia, while earlier menopause predominated in low-resource settings such as India and Pakistan. These comparisons are limited by unequal representation across regions. Consistent associations were noted with education, BMI, smoking, alcohol use, and reproductive history.

These regional differences have important clinical and public health implications. Earlier menopause is linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, and cognitive decline, suggesting a need for early preventive strategies in countries where ANM is lower.

Public health policies focused on improving women’s education, nutrition, and access to reproductive health care may help delay menopause onset and promote healthier aging. In addition, targeted interventions to reduce smoking and harmful alcohol use could further mitigate risks associated with early menopause.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: There are no conflicts of interest.
